answers.answer: Hi, well.  I think I think it is hard at this point.  Here's the thing, the specialty with the MOST lawsuits is obstetrics.  Doctors in obstetrics carry very high malpractice insurance.  There are all sorts of things that can go wrong naturally (and doctors are blamed) and of course mistakes happen from time to time.  But in general, young women are told to go home and labor there until it is closer to the birth and the doctor is giving them instruction that is based on their experience very safe.  Same for labor and delivery nurses.  It's frustrating when you are the patient but in general, they are usually right and giving safe advice.It's hard to wait.  It's uncomfortable.  Most women feel exactly the same way in the end.  And then they have their baby and it is over.So, I would try to trust the doctor.  She's been in and checked and they gave her their advice.  They know the risks and consequences for a mistake so are probably not as nonchalant as it appears.luck to your sister in law

well  I ha  the same thing my cocontractions ere every 7 minutes an  my doctor decided to give me a shot so they would go away and as for her she even had a high blood pressure and thy won't tell her anythng she had to switch hospitals because she was discriminated at the old one..n I know that if u have a high blood pressure they do help you really quick because on my 1st pregnancy I was going thru that and my doctor helpd me and she has never  had problems on any pregnancy this is her 3 rd baby

She could always get a second opinion. My cousin went to a hospital that sent her home, she decided to get a second opinion at a different hospital and ended up delivering her baby in the car because she didn't make it there in time. If you're sister in law is really worried then I'd say look into it

High blood pressure is one thing and different than preeclampsia.  I had pregnancy hypertension---  quite high blood pressure but it did not turn into life threatening preeclampsia.  Important to remember that.That this is her third pregnancy, that is telling that something is different.  A lot of first time moms do not understand that they will be very uncomfortable and labor for some time prior actually being admitted to L&D and they just fight it when it is perfectly safe and the norm.But if her gut says something is wrong, she should go back to labor and delivery.  10 minute apart contractions is pretty far apart.  She's almost to the end, right?   So, she wouldn't be given a shot to stop contractions, they have to let her labor it out.  Most doctors do not admit someone that is probably a couple days off from having their child or even one to go through contractions.  They want to admit women in active labor and not in the early phases.  But again, if her gut says something is wrong, she should go back or leave increasingly clear messages to her doctor that she needs help to understand what is going on.luck to her.  It's never an easy time in the end and can be confusing to a mom.  peace
Oh, and what I meant about hypertension is that they don't deliver just for hypertension----  it has to reach the stage of preeclampsia.  I went 10 days past my due date with hypertension.
